name: Pierpont prime
rephrased: Pierpont primes are prime numbers that can be written as 2 raised to some nonnegative integer power u, multiplied by 3 raised to some nonnegative integer power v, and then adding one.
implication_form: There is no 'If P, then Q' form because the definition itself states the condition for a number to be a Pierpont prime.
explained: In number theory, a Pierpont prime is a prime number of the form 2ᵘ * 3ᵛ + 1 for some nonnegative integers u and v. That is, they are the prime numbers p for which p − 1 is a 3-smooth number (i.e., its prime factors are only 2 and 3). They are named after the mathematician James Pierpont, who used them to characterize polygons that can be constructed with compass, straightedge, and a marked ruler (also known as a straightedge and compass with a fixed angle).
related_conjectures: Infinitude of primes of the form 2ᵘ * 3ᵛ + 1
